description: Perhaps an American English blend of flutter and hurry. Alternatively, perhaps from an obsolete term flurr (“scatter”).

entries.meaning: A sudden and brief blast or gust; a light, temporary breeze.
A shower of dust, leaves etc. brought on by a sudden gust of wind.

examples: These [argument structure] modifications are important because they have provoked a flurry of investigation into argument structure operations of merger, demotion etc.

entries.meaning: A snack consisting of soft ice cream mixed with small pieces of fruit, cookie crumbs, etc.
examples: Does your "Forbidden Foods" list include banana splits, ice cream sundaes, slurpies, popsicles, frozen yogurts, milk shakes, and ice cream flurries? These foods taste great but have a reputation for being bad for your health.

entries.meaning: The violent spasms of a dying whale.
An occurrence of something (countable instances) in large numbers, happening suddenly or in a short period of time.
examples: The fencer landed a flurry of hits on her opponent.
The think piece provoked a flurry of media responses for the remainder of the week.

verbs.description: flurry (third-person singular simple present flurries, present participle flurrying, simple past and past participle flurried)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move or fall in a flurry.
